bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lloyd D. LeMan, February 10, 1942

div1.p: Hench reports that he is still searching for photographs of Columbia Barracks and Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lloyd D. LeMan, February 10, 1942
div1.opener:
Copy to Miss Mina Maxwell
Room 3023, Munitions Bldg.
Office of the Chief Signal Officer
Photographic Division
Washington, D. C.
Y. F.
February 10, 1942
Major Lloyd D. Leman
Office of the Chief Signal Officer
Photographic Division, U. S. Signal Corps
Munitions Bldg.
Washington, D. C.
Your file
O C Sig O 004.511
(1-3-42)
My dear Major Leman:

list.item:
1. Last month I was glad to be able to go over the old photographs of
Cuba taken in 1899-1901, etc. by the Signal Corps. I was especially anxious to
find photographs of Camp Columbia (Columbia Barracks) near Quemados de Marianao
(suburb of Navana) as of 1900. With the very generous and courteous help of Miss
Mina Maxwell I found three photos of Camp Columbia taken in 1908 (S C 113424 -
113425 - 113426) but only one taken in 1900 (106187). I note that the three
1908 photos are also numbered M.I.D. - 94, 95 and 96. Since returning home I
wondered whether the indication “M.I.D.” referred to another file of photos which
I might not have seen. I would appreciate it greatly if you would ask Miss Max-
well whether I saw the file M. I. D. also. If not, perhaps there are more photos
of Camp Columbia which I could get.

2. We never did find any photos of Camp Lazear. This was the special
“experimental sanitary station” set up by Walter Reed a mile away from Camp Columbia. I
It was in Quemados de Marianao and was in existence from November, 1900 to March,
1901. Photographs of it appear in Dr. Kelly's book “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
(1906) and two photos of it appear next to page 188 in the Report of the Surgeon
General of the Army to the Secretary of War for the fiscal year ending June 30,
1901 (Wash. Govt. Printing Office, 1901). These photos are none too good for
copying purposes, hence I am very anxious to locate the original negatives; besides
that I hope there may have been other unpublished photos taken. In the Surgeon
General's Report and elsewhere the station is labelled “Camp Lazear, the Experi-
mental Sanitary Station near Quemados, Cuba.” Miss Maxwell could find nothing
labelled “Camp Lazear”. Do you suppose these films might be found in some other
file under the label “Experimental Sanitary Station”, etc.? Or do you think I
might find these negatives in some other department's photographic files (Adjutant
General's Dept., Quartermaster's Dept., etc.)? They are not in the files of the
Surgeon-General's Dept. Mr. Reeves and I searched them thoroughly. I would greatly
appreciate your further help in this matter.

3. I am returning herewith two photos S C 1806 and S C 4094 which were
sent me by mistake instead of R B 1806 (Havana, surrender) and R B 4094 (Pinar
Major Lloyd D. Leman
- 2 -
February 10, 1942
del Rio Barracks). I would appreciate receiving the two correct prints. I have
already paid for them. The work order was numbered 4808, dated January 16, 1942.

div1.p:
Let me express again my very sincere appreciation for the courtesies
extended to me by yourself and Miss Maxwell.

closer.seg:
P.S. For your convenience, I am sending a carbon copy of this letter
to Miss Maxwell.
